etymology.description: 肉(肉) (ròu, "flesh") + 夜(夜) (yè, "night") = part of the body associated with night -> armpit
etymology.interpretation: The character 腋(yè, "armpit") combines the semantic element 肉(肉) (ròu, "flesh") indicating its association with the body, and the phonetic component 夜(夜) (yè, "night") contributing the sound. The use of 夜 is purely phonetic and the character originally used to be written as 亦, which suggests an historical borrowing of the phonetic element for armpit.

examples.chinese: 他的腋流着汗珠(他的腋流著汗珠)。
examples.english: Beads of sweat stream from his armpit.

examples.chinese: 运动后(運動後)，他的腋开始刺痛(他的腋開始刺痛)。
examples.pinyin: Yùndòng hòu, tā de yè kāishǐ cìtòng.
examples.english: After exercising, his armpit began to sting.

examples.chinese: 夏日午后(夏日午後)，清风拂过腋边(清風拂過腋邊)。
examples.pinyin: Xiàrì wǔhòu, qīngfēng fúguò yè biān.
examples.english: On a summer afternoon, a gentle breeze brushed past his armpit.
